newsitem.title: FRANCE: Renault loses more ground on layoff move.
newsitem.headline: Renault loses more ground on layoff move.

text.p: French carmaker Renault SA lost further ground on Thursday as political and union fallout continued from its plans to lay off workers in Belgium and France.

The carmaker, still 46 percent state-owned, was down 2.95 percent to 135.10 francs at 1058 GMT in volume of 107,855 shares traded. "The possibility that Renault will be forced to modify its plans seems to be rising," said one broker.
The European Commission said on Wednesday that Renault had clearly breached European Union directives in its handling of plans to close its Belgian assembly plant.

French Prime Minister Juppe has asked Renault chairman Louis Schweitzer to "undertake, without delay, all useful consultation" while President Jacques Chirac has said he was shocked by Renault's method.
Meanwhile, a spokeswoman for Renault said on Thursday the carmaker has told Belgian workers protesting over the Vilvoorde plant closure it could transfer some Belgian staff to France.
She gave no numbers but said Schweitzer wanted to meet Belgian staff representatives at a formal works council meeting and was waiting for a date to be fixed.

Renault's plans to shut the Vilvoorde plant in June would mean the loss of 3,100 direct jobs. It has also said it plans to cut 2,764 jobs in France and transfer more than 1,000 other French workers this year.
